evidence_base: Olympic and professional athlete training research

exercises.scientific_explanation: The power clean develops maximum power output through triple extension, with elite athletes generating >5000 watts. Garhammer's research shows optimal power development occurs at 70-80% 1RM. The exercise improves rate of force development by 18-25% and transfers directly to jumping and sprinting performance through similar movement patterns.
research_citations: Comfort et al. (2012): Power clean training effects
exercises.form_cue: Explosive hip extension, high elbows in catch, receive in quarter squat
exercises.common_mistake: Arm pull before hip extension reduces power by 15-20% and increases injury risk

exercises.scientific_explanation: The hang clean eliminates the technical demands of the first pull while maintaining the power development benefits. Research shows similar power outputs to full clean when performed from knee level. The exercise teaches proper second pull mechanics and Olympic lifting receiving positions with reduced complexity.
research_citations: Comfort et al. (2011): Hang clean vs power clean comparison
Kawamori et al. (2006): Teaching progression effectiveness
exercises.form_cue: Start at mid-thigh, explosive hip and knee extension, high elbows to catch
exercises.common_mistake: Starting position too high reduces stretch-shortening cycle benefit

exercises.scientific_explanation: The depth jump exploits the stretch-shortening cycle to develop reactive strength index. Verkhoshansky's research establishes optimal drop heights of 0.3-0.8m based on individual strength levels. Ground contact times must remain <200ms to maintain plyometric stimulus. Studies show 25-35% improvements in vertical jump when performed correctly.
exercises.form_cue: Step off box, land and explode upward immediately with minimal ground contact
exercises.common_mistake: Contact times >250ms reduce plyometric effect by 40% and become jumping practice

exercises.scientific_explanation: Medicine ball slams develop concentric power without eccentric braking, allowing for maximum velocity development. Research shows power outputs comparable to Olympic lifts when performed at optimal loads (10-15% body weight). The exercise trains the entire kinetic chain in an explosive pattern applicable to many sports.
research_citations: Stockbrugger & Haennel (2003): Medicine ball training effects
Ignjatovic et al. (2012): Medicine ball power development
exercises.form_cue: Full body extension, slam ball down with maximum force, follow through completely
exercises.common_mistake: Using arms only instead of full kinetic chain reduces power development

exercises.scientific_explanation: Lateral bounds develop frontal plane power and stability essential for cutting sports. Research shows 20-30% improvements in change of direction speed after 6-week training. The exercise challenges the gluteus medius and deep hip stabilizers while developing unilateral power in the frontal plane.
research_citations: Young & Farrow (2006): Change of direction training
Bourgeois et al. (2017): Lateral plyometric training
exercises.form_cue: Land on single leg, stick the landing, bound laterally to opposite leg
exercises.common_mistake: Not sticking single-leg landing reduces stability training benefits

exercises.scientific_explanation: Quadruped thoracic rotation specifically targets the thoracic spine while stabilizing the lumbar region. Research demonstrates 10-15Â° improvements in thoracic rotation after 4-week protocols. The position allows isolated thoracic movement while preventing lumbar compensation patterns common in standing rotations.
research_citations: Theisen et al. (2014): Spinal rotation exercises
exercises.form_cue: Hand behind head, rotate only through mid-back, keep hips square
exercises.common_mistake: Lumbar rotation instead of thoracic reduces targeted mobility gains
